subject: Re: [junit] Re: Will JUnit 'fail()' trip up ALL code coverage tools?
msgSnippet: ... Hm. Has it hurt the team yet that you re now relying on Clover to run all your tests? I d be worried about that. -- J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger Diaspar
messageBody:
Neil Swingler wrote:
> There are other idioms for testing exceptions which will actually be supported by using clover.
> e.g.
> try
> {
> somethingDangerous();
> }
> catch(Exception exception)
> {
> assertEquals("message", exception.getMessage());
> }
>
> in this case clover will warn you if the test passed but the exception was never thrown i.e. we don't need the fail any more because we've got clover

Hm. Has it hurt the team yet that you're now relying on Clover to run
all your tests? I'd be worried about that.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
2005 Gordon Pask Award Winner for contribution to Agile practice
Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
